intro: Quercus faginea var. mirbeckii, commonly known as the Hungarian oak, is a variant of the common oak found primarily in Central and Eastern Europe. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters, featuring a broad, spreading crown. The leaves are lobed and often have a distinctive wavy margin, and they turn yellow in autumn. Its acorns are small, with a chestnut-like cap, and are an important food source for various wildlife. This species is adapted to a variety of soil types but prefers well-drained, loamy soils.
